dict.string:
Crash diets are usually
deficient in some nutrients.
This may be true.

It is difficult to obtain
all the essential nutrients
from food alone if we consume
less than 1000 kilocalories
per day, and certainly if
we have less than
800 kilocalories.

The nutrients which may
be lacking in a crash diet
are protein, the vitamins
folacin, vitamin B-1,
vitamin B-2 and vitamin B-6,
the minerals potassium,
magnesium and zinc,
and dietary fibre.

It is possible to increase
the nutritional quality of
low energy diets by including
nutrient-rich foods like liver,
wheat germ and yeast. Energy
intakes lower than 800 kilocalories
per day must be accompanied by
nutrient supplements or be provided
by formula feeds, under
medical supervision.
